node.text:
In this short video, our #Burgundy reviewer @wgfkelley catches up with Thomas Bouley from Domaine Jean Marc Bouley to discuss Pommard 1er Cru Fremiers.

Thomas Bouley is one of contemporary Burgundy's finest vignerons, and the most complete wine in his cellar is often his superb Pommard Fremiers. He also makes Volnay Caillerets and Pommard Rugiens, much more famous climats that tend to get all the attention...

node.title: William Kelley Chats with Thomas Bouley on Pommard 1er Cru Fremiers

node.text: Burgundy’s labels are decorative, even iconic; but they’re also a fascinating window onto the region’s social history. In this short video @wgfkelley explains why famous and little-heard-of producers share a label, and how this reminds us on the domaine bottling movement’s origins.

node.text: In the final part of the Burgundian Vignoble series @wgfkelley looks below the surface, at the drains and even cisterns that lie beneath the surface of some #Burgundian #vineyards, influencing their capacity to retain water or to remove an excess. He's seen eleventh-century cisterns in the Mâconnais, but this especially impressive example in the Côte de Nuits is around a century old. Burgundy is full of surprises!

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: Cisterns & Drains (Part 3 of 3)

node.text: In this video by @wgfkelley explains how powerful machinery came onto the scene in the late 20th century. Not only were murgers demolished and contours smoothed, but land previously unsuitable for planting was reclaimed. The commune of Meursault was a pioneer of this, using heavy machinery to pulverize stones in the Chaumes de Narvaux, Casse Têtes and Perrières. This new vineyard land was leased to young growers by the commune. Today, rather than removing stones by hand prior to replanting, it’s more and more common to see growers choosing to break up rocks mechanically and recontour their vineyards, which has consequences for soil structure. It’s another reminder that the Burgundian vignoble is a man made landscape...

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: Heavy Machinery (Part 2 of 3)

node.text: The #Burgundian landscape has been planted to vines for so long that it’s easy to forget that creating a #vineyard is often more complicated than merely planting vines. In this short video @wgfkelley discusses how, over the centuries, rocks were removed to build « murgers », create soils and smooth contours. Including a cameo by William's flower-gathering three year old daughter 🤣

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: The Landscape (Part 1 of 3)

node.text: In this short video, Emmanuel Guillot of @guillotbroux talks about restoring and replanting the abandoned walled #vineyards of Cruzille, overtaken by the forest in the aftermath of #phylloxera. A labor of love for future generations!

node.text: During a fascinating vertical tasting with @domainejmvincent we took time to visit the vineyards, including Jean-Marc’s high density plantings of #Chardonnay at the northern end of Les Gravières (where the soils are white marl, unlike the rest of this large climat). This domaine is one of @wgfkelley's favorites in Burgundy, and the 2019s are their best wines to date! But more about that soon in the pages of @wine_advocate

node.title: Jean-Marc Vincent on his high density plantings in Santenay

node.text: 🔊 SOUND ON: In this video, our #Champagne reviewer @wgfkelley discuss how Champagne ages - as well as how its aging trajectory differs from other wines - while opening a 1964 Royale Réserve from Philipponnat.

node.title: Thoughts On Old #Champagne by William Kelley

node.text: @michelebernetti brings us inside Marche and Abruzzo, two regions farmed by @umanironchi. Verdicchio and Montepulciano are discussed, and how did the Pecorino grape really get its name? This and more. Enjoy 🇮🇹 🍷

node.text: Filippo Chia paints us a big portrait of Montalcino and his Brunello from @filippocastelloromitorio. If you want to learn more about the Montalcino wine territory, I highly recommend this episode of the Italian Wine Series 🇮🇹 🍷 It’s packed with fascinating information

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Robert Parker Wine Advocate on September 09, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
With another season, another lap around the sun and another summer nearing its end, we take a look at some #Harvest21 pics and wish all #winemakers the best of luck for #vintage2021 🌤️🙏🍇🍷

📷: 1.@josemariadafonsecavinhos 2.@chateauderey 3.@deepixstudio 4.@travel_langhe 5.@spottswoodewinery 6.@soterwines 7.@silverheightsvineyard 8.@lopezfamilyvineyards 9.@quinta_da_pacheca 10.@domaenewachau

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Australia: More Recent Releases from South Australia.

Although many of those wines are indeed stereotypical big reds made predominantly from #Shiraz, Cabernet and Grenache, there’s enough variety to keep things interesting. Rieslings from the Clare and Eden Valleys and Chardonnays, Sauvignon Blancs and sparkling wines from the Adelaide Hills all make for high-quality palate-refreshers between red wines. They also don’t attain the jaw-dropping price tags seen on some of the trophy reds.

📖 Read @joeczinsta's full report with 300+ tasting notes via link in bio. 

📷 @twohandswines

RECENTLY PUBLISHED:  Portugal: Wines of Interest from the Dog Days of August.

This is a short, end-of-summer roundup, but even in the dog days of summer, Portugal keeps on producing interesting things that are definitely worth a woof or two. We have a large Dão group this issue. Let’s start off with the familiar name. Casa da Passarella again demonstrates its ability to excel at both the high and value ends...

📖 @mark_squires_wine's full report with 70+ tasting notes via link in bio.

📷 @casadapassarella

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Italy, Campania: New Releases from Italy’s Happy Place.

The ancients referred to the southern Italian region of Campania as Campania Felix, or “happy land”... This report contains 346 reviews of the wines of Campania. We cover wine styles from the main grape growing areas: Caserta, Benevento, Avellino, Napoli and Salerno. The dozens of grape varieties included here point to the stunning biodiversity amassed in Campania, thanks to ancient trade routes. We know that many grapes such as Greco and Aglianico (its name comes from “Hellenic”) arrived to the Italian peninsula during that period of enormous prosperity under Magna Graecia. The ancient Romans famously banqueted with wines made with Falanghina. Piedirosso is blended into Lacryma Christi red wines, named after the “tears of Christ” shed over Lucifer’s fall from heaven. His tears fell onto the scorched earth and lava flows of Vesuvius, and grapevines magically appeared in their place.

📖 Read @monicalarner's full report and 300+ tasting notes via link in bio.

📷 @monicalarner & @stefaniabarbot

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Chile: Current Releases

It’s tough to get a pulse of what’s happening in these circumstances, and the people making the wines are also living and working through exceptional and anomalous circumstances. So, it’s all so weird. But the world doesn’t stop, nature doesn’t stop, seasons come and go and a new vintage arrives sooner than one thinks. It’s been some 18 months since our last article about the country...

Read @luisgutierrezsd's full review with 900+ tasting notes via link in bio.

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED:  USA, Emerging Regions, East Coast: New Jersey’s Latest

This is the latest excursion into New Jersey, unquestionably a region that is showing some development, but it's still trying to emerge onto another level... There are plenty of nice wines, including the Working Dog Viognier, the Hawk Haven Pinot Grigio and Albariño (hard to pick between them), the Unionville Pheasant Hill Chardonnay (perhaps my favorite wine of the report) and Hunterdon Mistral Rosé, the Beneduce Vineyards Blaufränkisch (perhaps my favorite of the reds this issue) and Dry Riesling, and the Heritage Estate Semillon, among others.

📖 Read @mark_squires_wine's full report via link in bio.

📷 @workingdogwinery, @hawkhavenwinery & @unionvillevineyards

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Italy, Icons of #Tuscany: 20 Years of Bibi Graetz

Renegade winemaker and one of the most naturally optimistic people you could ever hope to meet, @bibigraetz is celebrating an important anniversary this year. His namesake brand is 20 years old, and Bibi says his bottles are “dressed up for a party.” The packaging of his two Sangiovese-based reds Colore and Testamatta boast a special silkscreened label with a pixelated version of his artwork.

📖 Read @monicalarner's full report via link in bio.

📷 @monicalarner

node.text:
In this short video, our #Burgundy reviewer @wgfkelley catches up with Thomas Bouley from Domaine Jean Marc Bouley to discuss Pommard 1er Cru Fremiers.

Thomas Bouley is one of contemporary Burgundy's finest vignerons, and the most complete wine in his cellar is often his superb Pommard Fremiers. He also makes Volnay Caillerets and Pommard Rugiens, much more famous climats that tend to get all the attention...

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Robert Parker Wine Advocate on August 29, 2021.

node.text:
RECENTLY RELEASED: USA, California: Fingers Crossed New Releases

It seems hard to believe that Fingers Crossed is now into its third bottling, the first release having been 2017. Since inception, it has been exhilarating to follow Nikolas and Julia Krankl building this operation from the ground up, each year bringing on new fruit sources, defining their signature and increasing volumes.

📖 Read @lisapbmw's full review via link in bio
📷 @fingerscrossedwine
